title: Definition of Conditional Formatting
text: Conditional formatting in Google Sheets allows you to automatically apply formatting—such as colors—based on the content of a cell. It's a way to visually highlight or draw attention to important cells in your tables and spreadsheets.

title: Named Ranges Function
text: Named ranges in Google Sheets allow you to assign a name to a range of cells. This can be useful for reference in formulas, but it does not automatically apply formatting or provide visual alerts for changing values, such as falling below a threshold.

title: Create a Filter Function
text: Creating a filter in Google Sheets enables you to view and sort data more efficiently. Filters allow you to focus on specific data points, but they do not automatically format or highlight cells based on conditions such as inventory falling below $$100$$ bags.

title: Alternating Colors Function
text: Alternating colors in a Google Sheet provides a visual distinction between rows or columns, which can make reading the data easier. However, it does not automatically change or update in response to changes in the data, such as inventory levels falling below a certain threshold.
